nodes.text: Word stimuli and color stimuli presented simultaneously produce interference in serial verbal reactions; specifically, the study tests whether habitual word-reading associations interfere more strongly with color naming than color stimuli interfere with word reading, and how practice modifies these interferences

Method: Novel simultaneous conflicting-stimulus paradigm â€” each stimulus symbol presents a color name printed in an ink color that names a different color, so each item contains a word stimulus and a color stimulus presented together; measures are reaction-time differences between conflicting and control presentations

Experiment 1 design: Measure interference of color stimuli upon reading words (RCNd vs RCNb); subjects read 100 color-name words printed in an ink color different from the named color and the same words printed in black, timing 100 responses per test

Experiment 2 and 3 designs: Experiment 2 measures interference of word stimuli upon naming colors (NCWd vs NC) using color squares versus word-printed colors; Experiment 3 studies practice effects by repeated daily practice on NCWd and testing transfer to NC and RCNd

Assumption: Strength of associations (word->read, color->name) reflects prior training and habitual responses, so differences in interference magnitude can be interpreted as differences in associative strength due to experience

Stimuli and controls: Five ink colors used (red, blue, green, brown, purple); no word printed in its own color; control tests printed in black and control color stimuli printed as solid shapes to isolate modality effects

Subjects and procedure: College students served as subjects; each read fixed sheets with counterbalanced order, practiced sample lines, timed with stopwatch, errors corrected or penalized via a preset correction rule

Materials novelty claim: Presenting word and color aspects of the same symbol simultaneously (word printed in a different ink color) differs from prior interference paradigms that changed response mappings after single-stimulus training
Result Experiment 1: Color stimuli produced only a small, nonreliable increase in time reading words: mean increase = 2.3 seconds per 100 items (5.6 percent), difference not statistically reliable

Result Experiment 2: Word stimuli produced a large, reliable interference on naming colors: mean time for 100 color namings increased from 63.3 s (NC) to 110.3 s (NCWd), an increase of 47.0 s or 74.3 percent; effect size several standard deviations and highly reliable

Result Experiment 3 (practice effects): Eight sessions of practice naming ink colors of words (NCWd) produced substantial improvement on NCWd (mean gain 16.8 s, 33.9 percent), partial transfer to NC (gain 4.0 s, 13.9 percent), and increased interference on RCNd (loss of speed on reading color-printed words)

Conclusion on asymmetry: Associations linking word stimuli to the reading response are stronger than associations linking color stimuli to the naming response; therefore word-reading habits interfere much more with color naming than colors interfere with word reading, consistent with differential prior training

Conclusion on practice permanence: Practice reduces but does not eliminate word-to-color interference; newly strengthened color-naming associations partially transfer to naming simple color stimuli and increase interference in the opposite direction (color->word), and the newly developed interference can decay rapidly with renewed practice on reading

Result on variability and individual differences: Practice on NCWd increased group variability (coefficient of variation rose); practice effects on variability differ by task: practice increased variability when strengthening the less habitual association (NCWd) and decreased variability when strengthening the more habitual reading association (RCNd)

Interpretation and applied claim: Difference in speed between reading color names and naming colors can be satisfactorily explained by differences in training and habitual association strength; word-reading is a more specific, stronger habit while color stimuli evoke multiple weaker responses

Sex difference observation: Females named colors faster than males across tests; practice reduced the sex difference on NC, supporting the view that the sex difference partly reflects acquired differences in training or habitual exposure to color naming
